page.title: 06 LEASOWE LIGHTHOUSE
page.content: Leasowe Lighthouse was completed in 1737 to guide ships safely into the Port of Liverpool. It was built of brick on a foundation of cotton bales which prevented it from sinking into the marshy land. Being 101 feet high, the 'keeper had to climb 130 steps each evening to tend to his lights. Locals, called 'The Wreckers', used to light fires on the sea-shore. This confused the sailors into running their ships aground where the cargo was plundered. Recently the lighthouse has become derelict since it was closed after the New Brighton lighthouse was built at the entrance to the River Mersey. However, the lighthouse may soon become used again, as a developer plans to convert the lighthouse into a public house.
